Bound for holy Palestine,</br>Nimbly we brush'd the level brine,</br>All in azure steel array'd;</br>O'er the wave our weapons play'd,</br>And made the dancing billows glow;</br>High upon the trophied prow,</br>Many a warrior-minstrel swung</br>His sounding harp, and boldly sung:

"Syrian virgins, wail and weep,</br>English Richard ploughs the deep!</br>Tremble, watchmen, as ye spy,</br>From distant towers, with anxious eye,</br>The radiant range of shield and lance</br>Down Damascus' hills advance:</br>From Sion's turrets as afar</br>Ye ken the march of Europe's war!</br>Saladin, thou savage king,</br>From Albion's isle revenge we bring!</br>On Acon's spiry citadel,</br>Though to the gale thy banners swell,</br>Pictur'd with the silver moon;</br>England shall end thy glory soon!</br>In vain, to break our firm array,</br>Thy brazen drums hoarse discord bray:</br>Those sounds our rising fury fan:</br>English Richard in the van,</br>On to victory we go,</br>A vaunting infidel the foe."

Blondel led the tuneful band,</br>And swept the wire with glowing hand.</br>Cyprus, from her rocky mound,</br>And Crete, with piny verdure crown'd,</br>Far along the smiling main</br>Echoed the prophetic strain.
Soon we kiss'd the sacred earth</br>That gave a murder'd Saviour birth:</br>Then, with ardour fresh endu'd,</br>Thus the solemn song renew'd.

"Lo, the toilsome voyage past,</br>Heaven's favour'd hills appear at last!</br>Object of our holy vow,</br>We tread the Tyrian valleys now.</br>From Carmel's almond-shaded steep</br>We feel the cheering fragrance creep.</br>O'er Engaddi's shrubs of balm</br>Waves the date-empurpled palm.</br>See, Lebanon's aspiring head</br>Wide his immortal umbrage spread!</br>Hail Calvary, thou mountain hoar,</br>Wet with our Redeemer's gore!</br>Ye trampled tombs, ye fanes forlorn,</br>Ye stones, by tears of pilgrims worn;</br>Your ravish'd honours to restore,</br>Fearless we climb this hostile shore!</br>And thou, the sepulchre of god!</br>By mocking pagans rudely trod,</br>Bereft of every aweful rite,</br>And quench'd thy lamps that beam'd so bright,</br>For thee, from Britain's distant coast,</br>Lo, Richard leads his faithful host!</br>Aloft in his heroic hand,</br>Blazing, like the beacon's brand,</br>O'er the far-affrighted fields,</br>Resistless Kaliburn he wields.</br>Proud Saracen, pollute no more</br>The shrines by martyrs built of yore!</br>From each wild mountain's trackless crown</br>In vain, thy gloomy castles frown:</br>Thy battering engines, huge and high,</br>In vain our steel-clad steeds defy;</br>And, rolling in terrific state,</br>On giant-wheels harsh thunders grate.</br>When eve has hush'd the buzzing camp,</br>Amid the moon-light vapours damp,</br>Thy necromantic forms, in vain,</br>Haunt us on the tented plain:</br>We bid those spectre-shapes avaunt,</br>Ashtaroth, and Termagaunt!</br>With many a demon, pale of hue,</br>Doom'd to drink the bitter dew</br>That drops from Macon's sooty tree,</br>Mid the dread grove of ebony.</br>Nor magic charms, nor fiends of hell,</br>The christian's holy courage quell.</br>Salem, in ancient majesty</br>Arise, and lift thee to the sky!</br>Soon on thy battlements divine</br>Shall wave the badge of Constantine.</br>Ye Barons, to the sun unfold</br>Our Cross with crimson wove and gold!"</br>
